p: The HEV infection in the yellow-necked mouse occurred chronologically later than in swine and wild boars since all samples collected from rodents from the earlier periods shown to be negative indicating that our A. flavicollis is a more recent HEV host and/or that it was recently infected and that the virus remains in the mouse for a shorter period. According to Maneerat et al.[ 41] active virus propagation with detectable HEV RNA in sera and feces of rats is possible early post-infection (up to 30 days). Furthermore, studies done on rats demonstrated non-persistent infections [ 42]. Therefore, time limited short viremia could be a reason for detecting only one positive A. flavicollis indicating that the percentage of Croatian rodents carrying HEV-3 could be higher. Unfortunately, due to a lack of sera samples we cannot foresee the real picture of rodent HEV-3 seroprevalence in Croatia.
